questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes a mastectomy for breast cancer. Post-operatively, the surgeon decides to use a closed suction drain. Which of the following drain types is shown in the image below?

choices.text: Penrose drain
Jackson Pratt drain
Romovac suction drain
Hemovac drain

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Jackson Pratt drain

Explanation:

The image shows a Jackson Pratt (JP) drain, which is a type of closed suction drain commonly used in various surgical procedures, including mastectomies.

 

Jackson Pratt drain:

  • Consists of a soft, flattened silicone tube connected to a soft plastic bulb
  • The bulb can be compressed to create negative pressure
  • Typically clear or translucent, allowing easy visualization of drainage
  • Suitable for various surgeries, including breast, plastic, and abdominal procedures
  • Easy to empty and maintain by patients

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is admitted with severe vomiting and requires placement of a gastric tube. The nurse sets up the feeding equipment as shown in the image. Which of the following tubes is correctly depicted in the image?

choices.text: Nasogastric tube
Infant feeding tube
Orogastric tube
Jejunal feeding tube

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Infant feeding tube

Explanation:

The tube depicted in the image is an infant feeding tube, which is smaller in diameter and more flexible compared to a standard nasogastric (NG) tube. Infant feeding tubes are specifically designed for use in newborns and young infants due to their smaller anatomy and inability to tolerate a larger NG tube.

 

Nasogastric (NG) Tubes: (Option A)

  • Inserted through the nose and passed into the stomach
  • Larger in diameter (typically 14-18 French)
  • Common markings:
    • Measurement markings in centimeters to indicate the insertion depth
    • 'STOMACH' printed on the tube to confirm correct placement
  • Indications:
    • Decompression of the stomach (e.g., in intestinal obstruction)
    • Enteral feeding in adults and older children
    • Medication administration

Infant Feeding Tubes: (Option B)

  • Smaller in diameter (typically 5-8 French) and more flexible
  • Suitable for newborns and young infants due to their smaller anatomy
  • No specific markings on the tube
  • Indications:
    • Enteral feeding in newborns and infants
    • Gastric decompression in infants
    • Medication administration in infants

  • Considerations:
    • NG tubes are generally not suitable for infants due to their larger size and rigidity, which can cause discomfort and potential complications.
    • Infant feeding tubes are specifically designed for the delicate anatomy of newborns and young infants, providing a more comfortable and safer option for enteral feeding and other applications.
    • Proper placement and monitoring of both NG and infant feeding tubes are crucial to ensure safe and effective use.


Orogastric tubes: (Option C)

  • These are inserted through the mouth, whereas the tube in the image is clearly a nasal tube, indicating it is either an NG or infant feeding tube.

 

A jejunal feeding tube: (Option D)

  • It is inserted beyond the stomach, into the jejunum, and has a different appearance compared to the tube shown in the image.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient undergoes a choledochotomy for the removal of common bile duct stones. The surgeon decides to use the given tube during the procedure.



Which of the following statements best describes its correct use and function in this scenario?

choices.text: It is inserted to provide long-term biliary drainage and should be left in place for several months.
It acts as a stent and is retained for 4-6 weeks in the distal filling defect.
It is used to create a biliary-enteric anastomosis and is removed immediately after surgery.
It is placed to perform intraoperative cholangiography and is removed before closing the incision.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It acts as a stent and is retained for 4-6 weeks in the distal filling defect.

Explanation:

The given image is of Kehr’s T-tube, used in bile duct surgeries, especially after Choledochotomy.

 

  • After the longitudinal incision in choledochotomy, the T-tube is inserted to act as a stent.
  • T-tube has a horizontal part which is placed in the CBD and vertical part which is allowed to come out, to drain bile.
  • Amount of bile draining daily is measured.
  • Before removal of the T-tube, patency of CBD should be confirmed.
  • T-tube is retained for 4-6 weeks in a distal filling defect.

 

  • The tube is not intended for long-term biliary drainage; it is typically left in place for 4-6 weeks, not several months (Option A ruled out).
  • The tube is not used for creating a biliary-enteric anastomosis; it is for temporary drainage and is not removed immediately after surgery (Option C ruled out).
  • Although the tube can assist in intraoperative cholangiography, it is not removed before closing the incision; it stays in place for postoperative monitoring and drainage (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with massive hematemesis. The physician uses an instrument given in the picture below. Which of the following statements is correct with respect to use of this device?

choices.text: This instrument is commonly used if variceal bleeding does not stop by banding/sclerotherapy/gluing.
The esophageal balloon is inflated first with 30-40 mmHg pressure, followed by gastric balloon inflation with 400 mL of air.
It is a definitive treatment and does not require further procedures like banding or sclerotherapy.
The most common complication associated with its use is pressure necrosis of esophageal mucosa.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. This instrument is commonly used when variceal bleeding does not stop after banding, sclerotherapy, or gluing.

  • The Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is a temporary balloon tamponade device used to control severe esophageal variceal bleeding when initial endoscopic treatments fail.

  • It acts as a bridge to definitive therapy (like band ligation, sclerotherapy, or TIPS).

  • Balloon inflation is done in sequence: gastric balloon first (250-300 mL air/saline), then esophageal balloon (20-40 mmHg).

  • Common complications include aspiration pneumonia, mucosal ulceration, and esophageal rupture.

Balloon Tamponade and Management of Variceal Bleeding

Aspect Details
Purpose Temporary control of bleeding in esophageal varices
Indications Bleeding uncontrolled by endoscopic treatment
Balloon inflation order Gastric balloon first, then esophageal balloon
Definitive treatments Endoscopic banding, sclerotherapy, TIPS
Common complications Aspiration pneumonia (most common), mucosal ulceration, esophageal rupture

 

The esophageal balloon is inflated first with 30-40 mmHg pressure, followed by gastric balloon inflation with 400 mL of air (Option B): Incorrect because the gastric balloon is inflated first to prevent esophageal rupture.

It is a definitive treatment and does not require further procedures like banding or sclerotherapy (Option C): Incorrect because the tube is only a temporary rescue device, and definitive treatments are still required afterward.

The most common complication associated with its use is pressure necrosis of the esophageal mucosa (Option D): Incorrect because the most common complication is aspiration, not pressure necrosis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with massive hematemesis. After initial stabilization, the decision is made to use the following device, as given in the picture below, for temporary management of suspected bleeding gastric varices.



Which of the following statements about the device is INCORRECT?

choices.text: The device shown in the picture is Sengstaken-Blakemore tube
It contains three lumens consisting of Esophageal and gastric aspiration port, and a port for balloon inflation
It has a single gastric balloon with capacity 500-600cc
It is used for temporary management of bleeding gastric varices

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The device shown in the picture is Sengstaken-Blakemore tube

Explanation:

The device shown in the image is Linton Nachlas tube, identified by the presence of a single inflatable balloon.

On the contrary, Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 2 balloons- Gastric and Oesophageal inflatable balloon, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the following instrument in the image is incorrect?

choices.text: The catheter is coated with silicone to minimize irritation during prolonged use.
For self-retaining purposes, the balloon is inflated with 20-30 ml of saline.
It can be used for administration of intravesical chemotherapy
2-way foley’s catheter can be used for bladder irrigation following TURP

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 2-way Foley’s catheter can be used for bladder irrigation following TURP

Explanation:

For bladder irrigation following TURP, 3-way Foley’s is used. The additional channel in the 3-way catheter is used for draining clots in patients with haematuria and clot retention, following transurethral prostate or bladder surgery.

Material
  • LATEX - Less irritation & crust formation
  • Silicone Coating- For Prolonged use (upto 3 months) (Option A)

Types
  • 2-way Foley catheter
  • 3-way Foley catheter

Channels

2-way Foley catheter:

  • Main channel: For drainage of urine
  • Small channel: For inflating balloon

3-way Foley catheter:

  • Main channel: for drainage of urine
  • Additional channel for irrigation

Balloon Inflation
  • 20-30 ml saline for self-retaining (Option B)
  • 30-50 ml of saline for hemostatic compression effect

Sizes (French scale)
  • Pediatric patients: 4, 6, 8, 10
  • Adult patients: 12, 14, 16, 18

Size Calculation
  • Outer diameter of catheter in mm = Fr/3 (Fr - French units)
  • E.g, if the size of the catheter is 18 French, then diameter = 18/3 = 6mm

Uses
  • To relieve urinary retention
  • To measure urine output
  • For administration of intravesical chemotherapy (Option C)
  • 3 ways catheter - for Irrigation after TURP
  • May be used for supra-pubic cystostomy

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient is rushed to the emergency department with symptoms of acute limb ischemia. The vascular surgeon diagnoses an arterial embolism and decides to perform an embolectomy. Which of the following catheters is specifically designed and most appropriate for this procedure?

choices.text: Swan-Ganz catheter
Fogarty Catheter
De-Pezzer Catheter
Malecot’s Catheter

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fogarty Catheter

Explanation:

Fogarty Embolectomy Catheter is used in embolectomy to treat arterial or venous thrombus/emboli in blood vessels.

The correct procedure for using the catheter:

  • Insertion through the clot
  • Inflation beyond the embolus
  • Withdrawal to remove the clot

 

  • Swan-Ganz catheter (Option A) is used for hemodynamic monitoring using pulmonary artery catheterization, not for embolectomy.

 

  • De-Pezzer Self-Retaining Catheter (Option C) & Malecot Catheter (Option D) are used for urinary drainage and related procedures, not for vascular embolectomy.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			a. Foley’s catheter
			
			
			1. 
			
		
		
			
			b. Nelaton’s catheter
			
			
			2. 
			
		
		
			
			c. Malecot’s catheter
			
			
			3. 
			
		
		
			
			d. Red-rubber catheter
			
			
			4.
questions.solution:
Answer: (A) a-3, b-4, c-1, d-2

Explanation:

Various catheters used in surgery-

A Malecot catheter is a self-retaining catheter with an umbrella or flower tip. It contains sulfur, hence is radio-opaque. It can be sterilized by boiling.

Uses:

  • Suprapubic cystostomy
  • Perinephric abscess
  • Amoebic liver abscess
  • Subphrenic abscess
  • Cholecystostomy

Fig: Malecot catheter

A Nelaton catheter is used for one-time emptying of the bladder during or after surgery.

Fig. Nelaton catheter

A red-rubber catheter is a non-self-retaining urinary catheter (has no balloon)

  • Tip: rounded and blunt
  • Uses: Temporarily used to drain urine from the bladder

Used to estimate the residual urine

Fig: Red -Rubber catheter

A Foley’s catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine.

  • It is also known as an indwelling catheter as it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time.

Fig: Foley’s catheter

questions.text: All of the following are true statements regarding central venous catheters except-

choices.text: The tip of the catheter is situated in the inferior vena cava
The most dangerous complication is pneumothorax
Inside OT, the Internal jugular vein is the preferred vein
In acutely injured, critically ill patients Femoral vein is the preferred vein

questions.solution:
Answer: A) The tip of the catheter is situated in the inferior vena cava

Explanation:

The tip of the central venous catheter is situated in the superior vena cava, not on the inferior vena cava.

The central venous catheter is used for fluid, medication, and nutrition administration.

  • The tip is located in the superior vena cava
  • Order of preference: Subclavian vein > Internal jugular vein > Femoral vein (Option D)
  • Inside OT: Internal jugular vein (Option C)
  • Outside OT: Subclavian vein
  • Complications: catheter-related sepsis, pneumothorax (Option B)

questions.text: What is the size of the cannula shown in the below image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 18G

Explanation:

  • The given cannula is an 18G IV cannula and its color code is green
  • The green cannula has a flow rate of 90 ml/min and it is used for administering blood products, irritant medications, in major surgery, contrast study

 

Sizes of Cannula:

questions.text: All of the following about chemo-port is true, except

choices.text: Retained for 5 years
Used for chemotherapy administration
The catheter is placed beneath the skin
The veins used are the internal jugular and subclavian veins.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retained for 5 years

Explanation:

  • Chemoport is an implantable venous access device which is placed beneath the skin. (Option C)
  • It is retained for 1-2 years.
  • The veins used are the internal jugular vein and the subclavian vein. (Option D)
  • Used for chemotherapy administration. (Option B)
  • In the chemo port, there are palpation pumps with which we can feel the presence of the septum.
  • Complications- catheter embolization, port occlusion, vascular thrombosis.
